ground_truth: A squad car, its siren wailing, kicks up dust as it roars into the foreground. Hi and Ed are seated on folding chairs facing an agent's desk. Hi wears a sport coat over his Hawaiian shirt, and Ed is in her dress blues. The agent looks, with a deadpan, from the file to Hi, his face still deadly neutral, then looks back down at the file and unfolds the accordioned rap sheet, revealing it to be a couple of feet long. Ed stares vacantly out the passenger window while they are driving. Hi looks from Ed out to the road. Over Hi's shoulder, he stares listlessly at himself in the mirror, a razor held forgotten in one hand, his face half-lathered and half-shaved. The bedroom is somewhat messy. Ed sits on the edge of the bed, also staring listlessly, her police uniform on but not yet buttoned, and her hands lie palm-up in her lap, like two dead fish. Hi works while his sweaty gum-chewing colleague stands idly by. Alone in his Chevy, he looks to the side at a 7-Eleven. Hi and Ed sit listlessly watching TV; Ed perks up reacting to something on TV. Hi notices her reaction and also sloughs off his stupor to watch a newscaster silently reading copy. Behind him, news footage of five nurses holding infants. Watching intently, Ed reaches her hand out to Hi, and he takes her hand in his. NATHAN ARIZONA, a stocky middle-aged man in a white polyester suit, gestures expansively with his white cowboy hat toward a one-story warehouse store with a football stadium parking lot, chroma-keyed in behind him. A businessman takes his newspaper and releases the machine door as he turns to leave, and Hi snags the door before it closes and takes his own five-finger discount copy. He flips the paper over to look at the headline, which reads: Arizona Quints Go Home. A pull back from the paper shows Hi and Ed reading it together at home. They look from the paper to each other. In the middle of the desert, we float in toward Ed who is seated, waiting, in the driver's seat of Hi's Chevy. Hi enters the frame and cinches down a ladder that is tied to the roof of the car, with pieces of red flag fluttering at either end of the ladder where it sticks out beyond the car. Hi gets in the car and it starts down the long, winding road leading away from the trailer, kicking up dust. Tableau of a couple at home. Nathan Arizona is on the telephone, his stocking feet up on an ottoman.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: A team vehicle, its klaxon wailing, stirs up particles as it roars into the forefront. Hi and Ed are seated on collapsible seats facing an operative's desk. Hi sports a blazer over his Hawaiian blouse, and Ed is in her ceremonial blues. NATHAN ARIZONA, a stocky middle-aged individual in a white polyester ensemble, gestures expansively with his white cowboy hat toward a one-story repository emporium with a football stadium parking space, chroma-keyed in behind him. test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: A squad car, siren blaring, kicks up dust as it speeds into view. Hi and Ed sit on folding chairs facing an agent's desk. Hi dons a sport coat and Hawaiian shirt; Ed wears her dress blues. The agent, with a deadpan expression, glances from the file to Hi, unfolds an extensive rap sheet, then looks back. Ed gazes vacantly out the passenger window while they drive. Hi checks on Ed and glances at the road. He stares at his mirror reflection, holding a forgotten razor, his face half-shaved. The bedroom is slightly messy. Ed sits on the bed, her uniform on but unbuttoned, hands limp in her lap. Hi works beside a gum-chewing colleague. Alone in his Chevy, he glances at a 7-Eleven. Hi and Ed watch TV listlessly; Ed reacts to something, prompting Hi to join in. News footage shows five nurses with infants, catching Ed's attention. She reaches out to Hi, who takes her hand. NATHAN ARIZONA, a stocky man in a white suit, gestures toward a warehouse store with a large parking lot. A businessman grabs his newspaper, and Hi snags one too. The headline reads: Arizona Quints Go Home. Hi and Ed read it together, exchanging glances. In the desert, Ed waits in Hi's Chevy. Hi secures a ladder to the roof and drives down a winding road away from the trailer, kicking up dust. Tableau of a couple at home. Nathan Arizona is on the phone, feet up on an ottoman.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: A wailing squad car roars into view. Hi and Ed sit on folding chairs facing an agent. Hi wears a sport coat, Ed her dress blues. The agent glances deadpan from a long rap sheet to Hi. Driving, Ed stares vacantly, while Hi looks from Ed to the road. Hi later glimpses himself half-shaved in the mirror. In their messy bedroom, Ed sits listless, her uniform unbuttoned. Hi works as his colleague idly chews gum. Alone, Hi eyes a 7-Eleven. Hi and Ed sit watching TV; Ed reacts, prompting Hi to notice the TV. They hold hands as five nurses with infants are shown behind a newscaster. NATHAN ARIZONA, stocky, middle-aged, in a white suit, gestures to a warehouse store. A businessman leaves a newspaper stand, and Hi grabs a paper, reading "Arizona Quints Go Home" with Ed. They glance at each other. In the desert, Ed waits in Hi's Chevy. Hi secures a ladder on the roof, gets in, and drives away, kicking up dust. At home, Nathan Arizona talks on the phone, feet on an ottoman.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: The loud wailing of a siren breaks the silence as a squad car, speeding energetically, kicks up a cloud of dust while roaring impressively into the foreground scene. Hi and Ed are both seated comfortably on simple folding chairs, which are positioned to face an agent's desk directly. Hi, attempting a casual yet presentable look, wears a sport coat over his vibrant Hawaiian shirt, while Ed is dressed in her formal dress blues, adding a touch of official importance to their presence. The agent, maintaining a neutral and expressionless demeanor, looks up from the file he is perusing to examine Hi briefly, before returning his attention back to the file. Methodically, he unfolds an accordioned rap sheet, revealing it to be unexpectedly lengthy, stretching out to a couple of feet. As they drive, Ed stares vacantly out of the passenger-side window, seemingly lost in thought. Hi, sitting beside her, glances from Ed to the road ahead, monitoring their journey. Over Hi's shoulder in the reflection, he looks listlessly at himself in the mirror as he holds a razor absentmindedly; his face is partially covered in lather with one half shaved and the other still soapy. The bedroom surrounding them is notably messy and disorganized. Ed, seated pensively on the edge of the bed, stares into space; her police uniform is on but remains unbuttoned, and her hands lie palm-up in her lap, motionless like two lifeless fish. While Hi busily works, his colleague, who is sweating and chewing gum, stands by idly, contributing little to the task at hand. Alone inside his Chevy, Hi casts a brief glance to the side at a nearby 7-Eleven convenience store. At home, Hi and Ed sit together in front of the television, seemingly listless, until Ed suddenly perks up, reacting to something of interest on the TV screen. Noticing her engagement, Hi rouses from his stupor and also watches as a newscaster silently reads a script. Behind the newscaster, footage depicts five nurses each holding an infant. Watching with interest, Ed reaches her hand toward Hi, and he affectionately takes it in his own. NATHAN ARIZONA, a robust, middle-aged man wearing a white polyester suit, grandly gestures with his white cowboy hat toward a one-story warehouse store, which is chroma-keyed behind him, complete with a vast parking lot reminiscent of a football stadium. Nearby, a businessman takes his newspaper from a vending machine, allowing the machine door to close as he turns to leave. Seizing the moment, Hi nimbly intercepts the door before it shuts completely, snagging his own five-finger discount copy. As he flips the paper over to examine the headline, it reads: Arizona Quints Go Home. Retracting from the newspaper, we see Hi and Ed engrossed in reading it together at home. They exchange meaningful glances from the paper to one another. In the vast expanse of the desert, our view floats toward Ed, who is patiently seated and waiting in the driver's seat of Hi's trusty Chevy. Hi enters the scene and proceeds to secure a ladder tied to the car’s roof, ensuring that pieces of red flag flutter conspicuously at each end where the ladder extends beyond the vehicle. Climbing into the car, Hi starts it up, and they drive down a long, winding road that leads away from their trailer, kicking up another cloud of dust as they depart. A tableau emerges of a couple in their home setting. Meanwhile, Nathan Arizona, speaking on the telephone, relaxes with his stocking feet propped up on an ottoman.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: The piercing and quite loud wailing of a siren abruptly shatters the peaceful silence, as a police squad car, moving rapidly with notable energy, kicks up a swirling cloud of dust in its wake while it roars impressively into the foreground of the scene. Hi and Ed find themselves seated comfortably in simple but practical folding chairs that are set up to face directly toward an agent’s desk. Hi, in an attempt to achieve a look that is casual yet presentable, dons a sport coat over his brightly colored Hawaiian shirt. Meanwhile, Ed is attired in her formal dress blues, adding an air of official importance to their presence. The agent, maintaining a neutral and entirely expressionless demeanor, briefly lifts his eyes from the file that he is carefully examining to scrutinize Hi, before turning his focus back to the document. With methodical precision, he unfolds an accordioned rap sheet, revealing it to be surprisingly lengthy, stretching out impressively to a couple of feet. As they drive together, Ed gazes vacantly out of the passenger-side window, appearing to be lost deep in thought. Hi, who is seated beside her, shifts his gaze from Ed to the open road ahead, attentively monitoring the journey. Over Hi's shoulder, in the reflection, he gazes listlessly at himself in the mirror while holding a razor absentmindedly; his face is partially covered in shaving lather, with one side smoothly shaved and the other still soapy. The bedroom is notably messy and quite disorganized, adding to the sense of chaos. Ed sits pensively on the edge of the bed, her gaze fixed in empty space; her police uniform is on her body but remains unbuttoned, and her hands rest palm-up in her lap, appearing motionless like two lifeless fish. While Hi busily works, his colleague, who is sweating and chewing gum, stands idly by, offering little contribution to the task at hand. Alone inside his Chevy, Hi casts a brief glance to the side at a nearby 7-Eleven convenience store, contemplating his next move. At home, Hi and Ed sit together in front of the television, appearing listless, until Ed suddenly perks up, reacting to something of interest on the TV screen. Noticing her sudden engagement, Hi rouses himself from his stupor and also begins to watch with interest as a newscaster silently reads a script. Behind the newscaster, footage shows five nurses, each one gently holding an infant. Watching with interest, Ed reaches her hand toward Hi, and he affectionately takes it in his own, conveying a silent connection. NATHAN ARIZONA, a robust, middle-aged man clad in a white polyester suit, grandly gestures with his white cowboy hat toward a one-story warehouse store, which is chroma-keyed behind him, complete with an expansive parking lot reminiscent of a football stadium. Nearby, a businessman retrieves his newspaper from a vending machine, allowing the machine door to swing shut as he casually turns to leave. Seizing the moment, Hi nimbly intercepts the closing door before it shuts completely, deftly snagging his own five-finger discount copy. As he flips the newspaper over to examine the bold headline, it reads: Arizona Quints Go Home. Retracting from the newspaper, we see Hi and Ed engrossed in reading it together in the comfort of their home. They exchange meaningful glances from the paper to one another, deepening their shared understanding. In the vast and expansive desert, our view floats toward Ed, who is patiently seated in the driver’s seat of Hi’s trusty Chevy, awaiting the next step. Hi enters the scene and proceeds to secure a ladder tied to the roof of the car, ensuring with care that pieces of red flag flutter conspicuously at each end where the ladder extends beyond the vehicle. Climbing into the car, Hi starts it up, and they drive down a long, winding road leading away from their modest trailer, sending another cloud of dust swirling as they depart. A tableau emerges of a couple in their home setting, sharing a sense of unity. Meanwhile, Nathan Arizona, speaking on the telephone, relaxes comfortably with his stocking-clad feet propped up on an ottoman, exuding an air of casual authority.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: As the siren of the squad car screams through the air, the vehicle propels itself forward with intense speed, causing a cloud of dust to rise and swirl around it as it emerges into the foreground. Inside an office, Hi and Ed sit on folding chairs positioned directly in front of the agent's desk, both of them silently awaiting the interaction to unfold. Hi is dressed in a sport coat layered over his vibrant Hawaiian shirt, exuding a casual air, while Ed, seated beside him, is formally clad in her meticulously pressed dress blues. Observing them with a face that remains expressionless, the agent lifts his gaze from the file to Hi, maintaining a neutral demeanor as he assesses him. He swiftly shifts his focus back down, deftly handling the file to extract the accordioned rap sheet, unfolding it until it stretches to an impressive length of a couple of feet. As their vehicle moves along the road, Ed gazes blankly out of the passenger window, seemingly lost in thought, while Hi alternates his gaze between Ed and the road ahead, a distant look crossing his face. Later, with a pensive expression, Hi glances over his shoulder to look into the mirror, holding a razor in one hand, its use momentarily forgotten, as he stares at his reflection—his face is half-covered in lather and the other half bears freshly shaved skin. The bedroom around them is somewhat cluttered, as Ed perches on the bed's edge, mirroring Hi's vacant stare; her police uniform hangs on her figure, unbuttoned, and her hands rest in her lap, facing upward and lifeless. At work, Hi stays focused on his tasks while his colleague, soaked in sweat and chewing gum, stands off to the side, contributing little. Alone in his Chevy, Hi casts a sideways glance at a nearby 7-Eleven, contemplating some unspoken thought. Later, Hi and Ed sit together, consumed by a sense of languor, as they watch TV with little engagement, until Ed suddenly becomes alert, reacting visibly to something occurring on the screen. Hi, noting Ed's heightened attention, shakes off his own torpor to follow her gaze, observing a newscaster who silently reads the news, backed by footage showing five nurses cradling infants. Deeply engrossed, Ed instinctively extends her hand towards Hi, who responds by gently clasping it in his, sharing in the moment. Meanwhile, NATHAN ARIZONA, a stout middle-aged man dressed in a striking white polyester suit, dramatically gestures with his white cowboy hat toward a large warehouse store, its sprawling parking lot as expansive as a football stadium, digitally imposed behind him for dramatic effect. As a businessman collects his newspaper from the vending machine and releases the door to depart, Hi opportunistically intercepts it before it closes, swiftly securing a newspaper without payment. He flips the paper around to examine the front-page headline, which reads: Arizona Quints Go Home. As the scene pulls back, Hi and Ed are revealed to be at home, reading the newspaper together, processing the information before shifting their gaze from the paper to each other, sharing a silent moment of understanding. In the desert's expansive emptiness, the camera smoothly closes in on Ed, who sits waiting in the driver's seat of Hi's Chevy, her demeanor one of quiet patience. Hi enters the frame, securing a ladder tied to the car's roof, ensuring it is firmly in place, with red flags flapping on either end where the ladder extends beyond the vehicle. Once assured that everything is secure, Hi joins Ed in the car, which begins its journey down a long and twisting road, leaving a trail of dust in its wake as it moves away from the trailer behind. The scene shifts to a tranquil domestic tableau, depicting a couple in their home setting, while Nathan Arizona appears engaged in a phone conversation, his feet comfortably propped up on an ottoman, clad only in socks, perfectly embodying a moment of casual authority.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: A squad car, siren wailing, speeds into view as Hi and Ed sit before an agent's desk. Hi, in a sport coat over his Hawaiian shirt, and Ed, in her dress blues, face the agent who scrutinizes Hi's extensive rap sheet. During their drive, Ed stares vacantly out the window while Hi casts a glance at both her and the road. Later, Hi, half-shaved and lost in thought, holds a razor before a messy bedroom, where Ed sits listlessly on the bed in her unbuttoned uniform. Hi works as his colleague idly chews gum nearby. Alone in his Chevy, Hi glances at a 7-Eleven. At home, Hi and Ed watch TV until Ed reacts to a broadcast about five nurses holding infants; she reaches for Hi's hand, and he takes it. NATHAN ARIZONA, a stocky middle-aged man in a white suit, gestures toward a large warehouse store. A businessman retrieves a newspaper from a machine, and Hi takes advantage of the open door to grab a copy, revealing the headline: "Arizona Quints Go Home." Hi and Ed read the paper together and exchange looks. In the desert, Ed waits in the driver’s seat of Hi's Chevy as he secures a ladder to the car roof, red flags fluttering at each end. Hi joins Ed, and they drive down the winding road, kicking up dust. In a home tableau, Nathan Arizona is on the phone with his feet up on an ottoman.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: A squad car, its siren wailing like a distress signal in the quiet town, kicks up dust as it roars into the foreground. Hi and Ed are seated on folding chairs facing an agent's desk, a stark setting often used in temporary interview rooms. Hi wears a sport coat over his Hawaiian shirt, creating an odd juxtaposition against Ed, who is in her dress blues, the formal uniform of a police officer in ceremonial situations. The agent looks, with a deadpan, from the file to Hi, his face still deadly neutral, as many seasoned officers tend to train themselves to be, then looks back down at the file and unfolds the accordioned rap sheet, revealing it to be a couple of feet long, typical of someone with a long history of minor infractions. Ed stares vacantly out the passenger window while they are driving through the wide-open roads of the Arizona desert. Hi looks from Ed out to the road that stretches endlessly ahead. Over Hi's shoulder, he stares listlessly at himself in the mirror, a razor held forgotten in one hand, his face half-lathered and half-shaved, in a room cluttered with the detritus of daily life. The bedroom is somewhat messy, evidence of their chaotic routine. Ed sits on the edge of the bed, also staring listlessly, her police uniform on but not yet buttoned, and her hands lie palm-up in her lap, like two dead fish, unnervingly still. Hi works in a factory where his sweaty gum-chewing colleague stands idly by, one of those workers who often contribute little to the task at hand. Alone in his Chevy, which has seen better days, he looks to the side at a 7-Eleven, a ubiquitous convenience store chain across America. Hi and Ed sit listlessly watching TV; Ed perks up reacting to something on TV, perhaps an unexpected plot twist or newsflash. Hi notices her reaction and also sloughs off his stupor to watch a newscaster silently reading copy, a skill honed by years in journalism. Behind him, news footage of five nurses holding infants, likely a story about a nearby hospital's successful delivery day. Watching intently, Ed reaches her hand out to Hi, and he takes her hand in his, their fingers interlocking in silent solidarity. Nathan Arizona, a stocky middle-aged man in a white polyester suit, common attire for business promotions, gestures expansively with his white cowboy hat toward a one-story warehouse store with a football stadium parking lot, chroma-keyed in behind him, illustrating the wonders of modern video editing. A businessman takes his newspaper and releases the machine door as he turns to leave, and Hi snags the door before it closes and takes his own five-finger discount copy, a term referring to petty theft. He flips the paper over to look at the headline, which reads: Arizona Quints Go Home, likely referring to a local media sensation of the quintuplets born to a prominent family. A pull back from the paper shows Hi and Ed reading it together at home. They look from the paper to each other, understanding the gravity of the story. In the middle of the desert, we float in toward Ed who is seated, waiting, in the driver's seat of Hi's Chevy, dust swirling in the air. Hi enters the frame and cinches down a ladder that is tied to the roof of the car, a practical and common method for transporting oversized items, with pieces of red flag fluttering at either end of the ladder where it sticks out beyond the car, serving as a safety marker. Hi gets in the car and it starts down the long, winding road leading away from the trailer, kicking up dust, leaving behind a solitary home amidst the arid landscape. Tableau of a couple at home. Nathan Arizona is on the telephone, his stocking feet up on an ottoman, a position of comfort and casual authority.

Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. Ed perks up reacting to something on TV. Hi notices her reaction and also sloughs off his stupor to watch a newscaster silently reading copy. Behind him news footage of five nurses holding infants. Watching intently Ed reaches her hand out to Hi and he takes her hand in his. NATHAN ARIZONA. a stocky middleaged man in a white polyester suit gestures expansively with his white cowboy hat toward a onestory warehouse store with a football stadium parking lot chromakeyed in behind him. A businessman takes his newspaper and releases the machine door as he turns to leave and Hi snags the door before it closes and takes his own fivefinger discount copy. He flips the paper over to look at the headline which reads Arizona Quints Go Home. A pull back from the paper shows Hi and Ed reading it together at home. They look from the paper to each other. In the middle of the desert we float in toward Ed who is seated waiting in the driver's seat of Hi's Chevy. Hi enters the frame and cinches down a ladder that is tied to the roof of the car with pieces of red flag fluttering at either end of the ladder where it sticks out beyond the car. Hi gets in the car and it starts down the long winding road leading away from the trailer kicking up dust. Tableau of a couple at home. Nathan Arizona is on the telephone his stocking feet up on an ottoman.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: A squad car its siren wailing kicks up dust as it roars into the foreground. Hi and Ed are seated on folding chairs facing an agent's desk. Hi wears a sport coat over his Hawaiian shirt and Ed is in her dress blues. The agent looks with a deadpan from the file to Hi his face still deadly neutral then looks back down at the file and unfolds the accordioned rap sheet revealing it to be a couple of feet long. Ed stares vacantly out the passenger window while they are driving. Hi looks from Ed out to the road. Over Hi's shoulder he stares listlessly at himself in the mirror. He flips the paper over to look at the headline which reads Arizona Quints Go Home. A pull back from the paper shows Hi and Ed reading it together at home. They look from the paper to each other. In the middle of the desert we float in toward Ed who is seated waiting in the driver's seat of Hi's Chevy. Hi enters the frame and cinches down a ladder that is tied to the roof of the car with pieces of red flag fluttering at either end of the ladder where it sticks out beyond the car. Hi gets in the car and it starts down the long winding road leading away from the trailer kicking up dust. Tableau of a couple at home. Nathan Arizona is on the telephone his stocking feet up on an ottoman.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: A squad car its siren wailing kicks up dust as it roars into the foreground. Hi and Ed are seated on folding chairs facing an agent's desk. Hi wears a sport coat over his Hawaiian shirt and Ed is in her dress blues. Hi gets in the car and it starts down the long winding road leading away from the trailer kicking up dust. Tableau of a couple at home. Nathan Arizona is on the telephone his stocking feet up on an ottoman.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: A fire truck, its horn blaring, kicks up leaves as it skids into the backdrop. Max and Jess are perched on beanbags facing a magician's podium. Max wears a trench coat over his plaid sweater, and Jess is in her evening gown. The magician glances, with a smirk, from the briefcase to Max, his face still eerily docile, then glances back down at the briefcase and unfolds the accordion-style map, showing it to be several yards long. Jess gazes absently out the sunroof while they are cycling. Max glances from Jess out to the path. Over Max's elbow, he peers blankly at himself in the reflection, a toothbrush held forgotten in one hand, his face half-covered in toothpaste and half-rinsed. The attic is somewhat cluttered. Jess perches on the edge of the sofa, also gazing blankly, her evening dress on but not yet zipped, and her hands rest palm-up in her lap, like two lifeless birds. Max drills while his sweaty bubble-blowing apprentice stands aimlessly by. Solo in his Ford, he peers to the side at a bakery. Max and Jess sit blankly watching cartoons; Jess perks up reacting to something on the screen. Max notices her reaction and also shrugs off his trance to watch a commentator silently reading notes. Behind him, documentary footage of five chefs holding pastries. Watching attentively, Jess extends her hand to Max, and he holds her hand in his. LOUIS COLORADO, a wiry elderly gentleman in a beige corduroy suit, gestures expressively with his black fedora toward a two-story bakery shop with a baseball field parking lot, CGI-ed in behind him. A traveler grabs his magazine and closes the vending machine as he turns to leave, and Max catches the flap before it shuts and grabs his own unpurchased edition. He turns the magazine over to look at the headline, which reads: Colorado Sweets Go Public. A zoom out from the magazine shows Max and Jess reading it together in their living room. They glance from the magazine to each other. In the middle of an orchard, we glide in toward Jess who is perched, waiting, in the passenger's seat of Max's Ford. Max enters the scene and tightens down a kayak that is strapped to the roof of the vehicle, with pieces of yellow string fluttering at either end of the kayak where it extends past the vehicle. Max climbs into the car and it rolls down the long, meandering path leading away from the cabin, kicking up leaves. Scene of a duo at their cottage. Louis Colorado is on the cell phone, his bare feet up on a footrest.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: A squad car arrives dramatically with Hi and Ed, sitting for an interview. Hi's sporting a coat over his Hawaiian shirt, while Ed wears her police uniform. The agent examines Hi's lengthy rap sheet. Ed gazes blankly out the window during the drive, and both Hi and Ed are caught in moments of listlessness, reflected in Hi's half-shaved face and Ed's unbuttoned uniform. Hi works alongside a nonchalant colleague and sits in his Chevy, eyeing a 7-Eleven. Watching TV together, Ed's interest is piqued by something on-screen, and she holds Hi's hand as they watch a newscaster. The screen shows nurses with infants, sparking a moment between them. NATHAN ARIZONA, a middle-aged man in a white suit, gestures towards a warehouse store. Hi sneaks a newspaper headlined "Arizona Quints Go Home," which he and Ed read at home. In the desert, Ed waits in Hi's Chevy as he secures a ladder to the roof, and they drive away, kicking up dust. Meanwhile, Nathan Arizona relaxes with his feet up, talking on the phone.
